The Biography of Shi Faming of Jiangling Prefecture in the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Shi Faming of Jiangling Prefecture in the Tang Dynasty, Shi Faming, was originally from Jingchu.
He was well-versed in sutras and treatises, and skilled in various writings. His eloquence flowed like a river, and his precepts were firm and correct.

The Biography of Shenwu of Shiyan Mountain in Runzhou during the Tang Dynasty. The Biography of Shenwu of Shiyan Mountain in Runzhou during the Tang Dynasty. Shi Shenwu, whose courtesy name was Tongxing, was the son of the Li family of Longxi.
His ancestors moved to Changshui in Wu during the turmoil of the Western Jin Dynasty.
His family had been Confucian scholars for generations. He became a student when he was young.
When he came of age, he suddenly contracted a serious illness, which seemed incurable.
How could he apply his efforts to make amends for his faults?
During the Kaiyuan period, he went to Vinaya Master Xiguang and requested the methods of Jivaka, observing the etiquette of a disciple.
The master taught him the methods of repentance, which are: first, doctrinal repentance; second, ritual repentance.
These two are what the sages bestow, and the practice must have evidence.
So in front of the Bodhi image, holding an unyielding heart, burning the finger that is difficult to give up.
At that time, there was a strange light like the moon, shining on the purple palace. Extreme suffering can move the spirits and gods, the utmost refinement can move heaven and earth.
It is indeed a difficult thing for humans!
In the fourth year of Tianbao, he received full ordination, and his body first wore black robes.
In the eighth year, he was praised for his extraordinary conduct, and his name was registered at the temple.
By his later years, he was even more seen to be suffering in his heart.
Every time he set up a Lotus Sutra ritual arena for ninety days, he entered the long recitation and mindfulness of the Buddha's samÄdhi, and in this he was present.
He said to his disciples:
The sun is obscured by clouds, but how can it be harmed? The wind moves through the empty sky without moving. If one truly understands delusion, what is not the nature?
He built a dwelling on the east of Laolao Mountain, in the middle of Shiya, reaching the immortal path.
The fierce beasts were tamed on the meditation platform, and auspicious clouds hung low over the Dharma hall.
In the middle of the night, a mountain spirit appeared and said to Wuzhu:
I am Cao Shi'an, the former Marquis of Xincheng of the Sui Dynasty. In life, I was a marquis, and in death, I am in charge of the southern peaks.
Now that the master has come to stay, I wish to offer this land forever for your practice.
After speaking, it disappeared.

Li Hua, a member of the Ministry of Personnel, and Cui Yi, a palace attendant censor, visited Wuzhu together. They asked about the superiority and inferiority of the teachings of Confucius and Laozi, and requested an explanation of their ranks.
He replied:

The scriptures of Lokaká¹£ema are all external to the mind. Those who savor them labor without realization, like withered flowers in a marsh, or a dry pond reflecting the moon. Compared to the Buddhist teachings, how far apart are they?
Thus they went back and forth, and the answers flowed like a stream.
Li Hua and Cui Yi folded their hands, unable to counter.
How dare anyone encroach upon the boundaries of the Buddhist gate that he defended?
Hua was the textual patriarch of the generation, and was on par with Xiao Yingshi, surpassing him in literary expression.
If there were such a Confucian, who could compete with him?

Whenever there were unruly people who doubted the sutras and challenged the Dharma, [Hua] would certainly use examples from his own life and things far away to enlighten them, answering with reason, and none did not lower their heads and submit.
In the spring of the tenth year, Xinmao, he fell ill and passed away sitting upright.
He lived to the age of sixty-three, and his years as a monk were twenty-six.
On the day of cremation, more than five hundred relics were obtained, with pearl-like grains strung together, shining brightly.
His disciples Zhan Yi, Yuan Yi, and others took charge of it and moved the stupa.
Biography of Chan Master Yuanchong of Mount Zhong in Jinling of the Tang Dynasty. Chan Master Yuanchong, whose secular surname was Wang, was a person from Lin'i in Langya.
He was a descendant of Jin's Prime Minister Shixing Wenxian Gongzi Hui. Since the downfall of the Southern Dynasties, his family had lived in Jurong.
From his ancestors down to him, either wise or sagacious.
Chong was an orphan prodigy, towering like a solitary mountain.
His mind was likened to a lotus flower, his body as pure as jade, unstained by worldly dust, his aspirations lofty and simple.

At the age of fifteen, he left home to study the Way, carrying his schoolbag to the grotto heavens, eating the morning clouds and sleeping on the evening clouds, taking Tao Yuanming and Xu Xun as his teachers, delving deeply into the subtle phrases, realizing the hidden truths on his own.

Fearing that the ultimate truth had not yet been fully integrated and liberation was still obstructed, he turned his heart to the Buddhist canon, fully understanding the Buddha's teachings, and equating the Three Teachings, his mind transcending the world.
Thus his fame spread throughout Wu and Yue, and the monastics and laypeople regarded him differently.

The Censor-in-Chief and Prefect of Runzhou, Qi Pingyang Gong, heard of his conduct and had long admired him. Coincidentally, when the government was selecting talented people, he was included among the first batch.

In the late Kaiyuan period, he followed Chan Master Guan of Waguan Temple to inquire about the essentials of the mind, day and night without slacking off, never forgetting to seek further understanding.
Master Guan then examined his bones, knowing he was a thousand-mile swift-footed horse, and thus bestowed the profound Dharma upon him.
He revered the spiritual platform, his mind penetrating and clear, able to discard the hundred gods, his mind's mirror hanging high, with no private secrets in the dust.
His fame and price then shone far, his reputation known to all, the virtuous ones of Jinling invited him to move to Qixia Temple, where he was assigned.
Over a decade passed, he served and diligently pursued the Way, with a proper order, often looked up to by the assembly.

In the first year of Zhide, he completely rejected worldly affairs, took his staff and left the prefecture, traveled through the capital, widely paid homage to enlightened masters, dwelled his mind in tranquil surroundings, rarely interacting with worldly currents.
He finally entered the Zhongnan Mountains, passed through the Wei Palace, reached Bailu, ascended to Lanxi, and in Mengchuan obtained the separate residence of Right Vice-Director Wang Wei.
Pines grew on the rocks, and water flowed under the pines. The king and officials burned incense in a quiet room, and when they met Chong, their spiritual connection was uninterrupted.
At that time, the world was not yet peaceful, and jackals and wolves caused trouble. The wise ministers and treasures of the state were sometimes in danger.

Xiao Sheren Xin, who was in charge of the court, and the right vice minister, both had great learning and outstanding talent, respected Confucianism and valued the Way. They happened to meet once and debated for a day, delving into the profound and seeking the hidden, their minds in agreement.
Wang and Xiao sighed and said:
The Buddha's teachings have people who understand them, so we should not speak lightly of them!

When he returned to the Luo River and ascended Mount Song, he thought of the essential teachings of Bodhidharma and attained the unity of the Avatamsaka Sutra. His reputation gradually rose, and the noble families admired him.
The famous virtuous ones in the capital all invited him to be the abbot.
His mind was on wuwei, and he was aloof and did not care.
He then roamed the human world, following the traces of spiritual adepts, and finally reached Wu, Yue, Tiantai, and Siming in the east, purifying his mind and nurturing his essence.

After several years, he had the far-reaching thought of Mount Zhong and flew his staff to his old residence, where he examined the cloud chambers. The monks and laypeople were all delighted, and the jade-like mountain shone again.

In the fifth year of the Dali era, the prefect of Nanyang, Fan Gong, who had a deep love for Chan meditation, went on a spring tour of the county. He bowed in the direction of the wind and consulted about the essentials of the Way, further adding the ritual of a teacher.
At that time, the monks and laypeople considered this temple to be spiritually superior, and many came to stay. The supervisor and protector needed to select a monk of high virtue.
They all agreed that no one could replace Chan Master Chong.
Chong frequently declined and pleaded earnestly, but the assembly all repeated it three times. Unable to refuse, he accepted the position and filled the gap, totaling twenty years.

Relying on the wealth of the four directions and the power of transforming through the Way, the eaves and ridgepoles are like clouds, and the vermilion and cinnabar are renewed daily. This is indeed the state of non-action yet doing everything.
Having accomplished his work, he retired and peacefully abided at the highest peak. The number of his disciples before and after is beyond calculation.
In the twelfth year of Dali, he showed signs of illness and spoke of returning, not taking any medicine or tonics.
On the second day of the eighth month, he passed away at the mountain temple, at the age of sixty-five.

At the end of his life, he ordered his disciples not to seal or plant trees. His disciples such as Ruquan and Chengan followed the master's instructions. On the eighth day of that month, he was buried on the sunny side of Sheshan. Following his will, a cave was made in the cliff, and the stones were piled up without polishing or cutting.
The disciples together erected a magnificent stele to record his transformative traces, which was erected at the gate of the temple.

Biography of Shen Yong of Dali Temple at Jiashan in Yuezhou during the Tang Dynasty. The Biography of Shen Yong of Dali Temple at Jiashan in Yuezhou during the Tang Dynasty. Shi Shen Yong, whose courtesy name was Daogong, had the surname Cai. Because of his official position, he lived in Jiyang, and Yong was born in this prefecture.
When his mother Xuan was first pregnant, there were many strange signs.

He was exceptionally intelligent and insightful from a young age.
At the age of twelve, he left his parents to study the Way and requested instruction from Master Jun at Fahua Temple.
Whenever he read the Confucian and Buddhist classics, he could recite them after reading them once.
His peers rarely did not admire him.
In the twenty-sixth year of Kaiyuan, by imperial decree he was ordained and belonged to Xiangyan Temple in Zhushi. His fame spread.
He followed Master Xuanying of Fahua Temple and became proficient in the Four Part Vinaya Commentary.
Xuanying recognized his aspirations and told others:

Up to the fifth summer, he was indeed proficient in expounding. Learners from the Wu and Yue regions followed him.

During the Tianbao period, he was invited by Guo Mizhi of his native prefecture to reside in the western cloister of Fale Temple. He expanded the Buddha's abode, with tiered pavilions touching the sky, half reflecting in the river's shadow, and the corridors and rooms were complete.
Later, he traveled to Chang'an and stayed at An Guosi Temple. Officials and nobles relied on his demeanor. Those who admired him came in a line of carriages.

He was about to greatly promote Chan and Vinaya, but suddenly encountered the chaos of the An Lushan rebellion. He returned east to the lakes and rivers, passing through Xiangyang. Imperial Inspector Yu Guangxian invited him to stay for several months.
At that time, Court Gentleman for Ceremonials Dou Shao and Court Gentleman for the Secretariat Yuan Xian, their admiration deepened, both received the essentials of the mind.
Wei Zichun, the Court Gentleman for Comprehensive Duty, a Tang official, was upright and well-versed in learning, and debated with him.
Zichun had his horns broken, and the entire assembly was amazed and impressed.
Court Gentleman Yuan Xian sighed and said:

At that time, people considered him eloquent.

Later, he returned to his hometown and stayed at Fahua Temple. The Imperial Censor Huangfu Zeng, the Judicial Official Zhang He, the Military Commissioner Yan Wei, the Military Official Lu Wei, the Magistrate of Zhuji Qiu Dan, and the Court Historian Chen Yunchu all wrote poems to each other. Lu Shishi wrote a preface to continue the travels of Zhizhe and Xu Ling, making it a local custom.
In addition to his practice of meditation, Yong often wrote commentaries and collected ten volumes of his works, with a preface by Huangfu Zeng.

From the Zhide era to the Dali era, he was frequently invited to ascend the platform to confer precepts, starting from Danyang and reaching Jinhua. All the monks along the way appointed him as their teacher.
Moreover, the road south of the county passes through Wuzhou, and there are no temples for over a hundred miles. Buddhist practitioners have nowhere to rest while traveling.
Yong wished to establish a Dharma bridge to provide rest for travelers, so he built a temple on Mount Jiao, which could serve as a sacred site for Buddhist practice.
The people of De County, including Qi Duwei Chen Shaochin and others, led the faithful to build a pure land, and it took a decade to complete the project.
Previously, Xu Hao, the former Vice Minister of the Ministry of Personnel, assisted in the Mingzhou region. He reported to the Prefect Huangfu Wen, requesting to grant the name Dali to the monastery.
Previously, Wu Jun, a Taoist of Zhongyue, wrote several heretical treatises to criticize and slander Buddhism, confusing the ignorant.

Chen Shaoyou, the Commissioner of the Central Region, requested Yong to decide which of the two teachings, Buddhism and Taoism, was the ultimate Way. He then adopted the Buddha's method of subduing wrong views and used Bao Lin's text of defeating demons, citing the city's defenses to correct the madness.
As soon as the banners and drums were raised, Wu Jun was defeated.
He then wrote the Treatise on Destroying Delusions and Overcoming Confusion in three scrolls. The Eastern Buddhism was revived, truly due to Yong's power.
In the end, he traveled to Tiantai and compiled a two-scroll local gazetteer, both of which are attached to the new treatise.

His forehead was broad and his jaw was full, with a wind-like elegance and a clear and lofty bearing. Whenever he was called to the court, he was always invited to sit on a separate seat. He was asked to be the leader of the monks, with the utmost respect and courtesy.

On the fourteenth day of the eleventh month in the fourth year of the Zhenyuan era, which was the year of the Wuxin, he fell ill. He instructed his disciples to sit in the lotus position and passed away peacefully in the Dharma Hall of the Dali era.
On the fourteenth day of the twelfth month, his spiritual image was enshrined in the northern hills of the temple, following the monastic regulations.
He lived to the age of seventy-nine, and his Dharma years were fifty.
The following year, in the eleventh month of winter, his stupa was finally built.

Lu Huai, the Proofreader of the Ministry of Secrets, wrote an inscription for him. His foremost disciples, Zhi Ang, Ling Che, Jin Ming, and Hui Zhao, all displayed sharp wit and transmitted the Chan and Vinaya teachings to each other.
In the eleventh year, Qiu Shangqing, the Vice Director of the Ministry of Civil Service, wrote a stele to record his virtues.

Biography of Venerable Yuanting of Yaoshan in Langzhou, Tang Dynasty Biography of Venerable Yuanting of Yaoshan in Langzhou, Tang Dynasty Shi Yuanting, with the secular surname Han, was a person from Jiangxian.

In the eighth year of Dali, he received full ordination from Vinaya Master Xicao at Hengyue Temple and said:
A great man should be free from dharmas and purify himself. How can he be so petty, attending to details and acting like a piece of cloth?
He then visited Chan Master Shitou and secretly realized the Dharma of the mind. He stayed at Yaoshan.
One night under the bright moon, he climbed to the peak, laughed out loud, and his voice was heard ninety miles east of Liyang.
That night, everyone in Liyang heard the sound and all said it was from the east. The next day, they asked around and searched for each other until they reached Yaoshan. The disciples said:
Was it the master laughing on the peak last night?
From then on, his reputation spread far and wide.
During the Yuanhe period, Li Ao was a member of the Censorate, and he was friendly with Li Jingjian.

Seeing you is not as good as hearing your name.
Yan then called out, and Ao responded. He said:
Prefect, why do you value the ears and despise the eyes?
Ao cupped his hands and thanked him, asking:
What is meant by the Way?
Yan pointed to the sky and to the water jar, saying:
The clouds are in the blue sky, the water is in the jar.
At that time, the dark room was already illuminated, and Ao's doubts suddenly melted away. He then composed a verse saying:
Your body is shaped like a crane, under a thousand pine trees, with two copies of the sutras.
I came to ask you, but you have nothing more to say, the clouds are in the blue sky, the water is in the bottle.
Another verse says, Choosing a secluded dwelling to suit my wild feelings, all year without visitors coming or going.
Sometimes I go straight to the peak of an isolated peak, under the moon, parting the clouds and laughing out loud.

The Biography of the Unknown of Tongde Temple in Luoyang of the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of the Unknown of Tongde Temple in Luoyang of the Tang Dynasty. Shi Wuming, whose surname was Gao, was a person from Bohai.
His ancestors served as officials in the Western Capital, so he became a person from Luoyang.

At a young age, his behavior was extraordinary. He did not eat meat or pungent foods, and he did not associate with noisy crowds. He was determined to leave the dust and dirt, and it was difficult for him to stay.

The Dharma I transmit has no name.

From then on, he traveled to all directions, wandering the Five Peaks, Mount Luofu, Mount Lu, Mount Shuangfeng, Mount Zhugong, Mount Luling, Mount Niutou, Yanxi, Mount Yao, Tiantai, and Siming, asking questions everywhere. In the sixth year of the Zhenyuan era, he went to visit the Five Terrace Mountains, staying nowhere in particular.

On the twelfth day of the twelfth month in the ninth year, he finished his meal at Fuguang Temple and sat upright in meditation, passing away at the age of seventy-two, with forty-three years as a monk.

When Bai Letian was demoted to the Prefect of Jiangzhou, he respected him the most.
Later, Li Bo was a Gentleman-in-Attendance. In the sixth year of Yuanhe, he retired to Mount Song and was summoned to serve as a compiler.

Li Bo was well-versed in many fields of knowledge, and there was no book in the hundred schools that he did not master, and he was called Li the Ten Thousand Volumes.

When he arrived in the prefecture, he was happy to meet Bai Letian. He talked about the most beautiful mountains and waters of Xunyang and Lushan, and the wise and virtuous people who had gone into seclusion.
Discussing the remaining traces of Huiyuan, he mentioned Chan Master Guizong, who was good at discussing the essentials of Chan. Li said:
When will the golden tablet of the imperial court have the name of a vegetarian Chan master?
Bai said:
If so, then I have not yet met a vegetarian Chan master.
Bai strongly encouraged him to visit the two forests, intending to see Chang together.

In the teachings it is said 'Mount Sumeru can be placed in a mustard seed, and a mustard seed can contain Mount Sumeru.' How can a mustard seed contain Mount Sumeru?
Chang said:
People say you have studied and read ten thousand scrolls of books, is that so?

I am ashamed of this empty reputation.

From the heels to the crown of the head, it is only a few feet of body, where are the ten thousand scrolls of books?

Later, there was a monk named Shenjian of Donglin Temple who lectured on various sutras and treatises. He asked about enlightenment in every sight and sound, and Chang briefly brought it up.

Biography of Xuanchang of Foshou Temple in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty. Biography of Xuanchang of Foshou Temple in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty. Shi Xuanchang, whose courtesy name was Shenzhi, was a layman surnamed Chen, from Xuancheng.

He then wrote the Record of Emperors of Successive Dynasties and presented it, but it was not approved.
